page.title: 05Alkerton Rectory
page.content: At the old rectory there is a remarkable door which is hinged in such a way that only half of it can be opened at a time. In 1665, the year of the plague the door was moved from the south side to the north. This it is said prevented the germs of the plague, which were coming from the south entering the house when the door was open. When the rectory was built there were 2 rooms downstairs, 2 rooms upstairs and 2 more rooms in the apex. The rectory may not be famous but the man who had it built was. Thomas Lydiatt was born at Alkerton where he lived for 30 years. When Prince Henry, son of James I, to whom Thomas was tutor died he came back to Alkerton to be rector of the parish. In 1945 more rooms were added & later a coal cellar & kitchen. There was an inglenook fireplace in the lounge circa 1626.
